description.value: Anonymi 3673 of the Convent of John Urtaya disliked Abraham II's appointment of Abraham III as his successor, believing him to be a lowly peasant. Sixty monks left the convent.
Anonymi 3675 established a monastery in Beth Bar 'rubtha.
Mar Samuel, prior to founding Mar Samuel Convent, visited the Convent of John Urtaya.
Mar Samuel stood on a column for a time before he began to build his convent. Abraham III sent his monks to help Mar Samuel build the convent.
Kawad, King of Persia attacked the City of Amida, slaughtered many people, took captives, and razed the Convent of John Urtaya in the year 502/3 A. Gr. 814
The story of Kawad's invasion was related to John of Ephesus years later when he was a white haired man, living in the monastery at Beth Gubrin.
King Kawad's invasion was devastating and drove many away from the Convent of John Urtaya. The white-haired man fled from Amida.
Another old man, named Paul of Arzen, related the history of the Convent of John Urtaya to John of Ephesus.
Paul was a monk in the Convent of John Urtaya when there were 400 monks residing within its walls, and shortly before King Kawad's invasion of Amida.
Because King Kawad's invasion destroyed the Convent of John Urtaya, Paul took up residence in Monastery in Orientals in Edessa.

Mar Samuel gained distinction in the conflict of persecution. Mar Samuel went into exile in the district of Claudias where he took up residence in the Convent of the Huts. He related the story of the establishment of the Convent of John Urtaya to John of Ephesus. This occurred 536/7 A. Gr. 848
Paul died during the second persecution sometime after 536.
The Convent of John Urtaya was rebuilt after King Kawad's invasion, but on a smaller scale--both in the number of buildings erected and in the number of monks admitted.
Abraham III died
Cosmas succeeded Abraham III as head of the Convent of John Urtaya and served during the reign of the Emperor Anastasius.
Cosmas died
Sergius succeeded Cosmas as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.
Mar Samuel died in 539
Sergius died in the first persecution in the monastery of Mar Mama
Symy succeeded Sergius I as the head of the Convent of John Urtaya in 522
Symy prophesied many things that came to pass, including his own death three and a half years after assuming the office of archimandrite.
Symy died three and a half years after assuming office in the Convent of the Poplars in 526
The monks of the Convent of John Urtaya who were in exile during the first persecution were allowed to return to their convent and inter Symy's bones there in 530
Abba succeeded Symy as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.
Before the Convent of John Urtaya was established there were a collection of huts on the site, named after Mar Afwrsm.
The Emperor Justinian began his reign in August 1, 527
The persecution was renewed through the descent of Ephraim and all of the convents were expelled in 536.
Abba and Anonymi 3677 went into exile and took up residence in the Convent of the Poplars.
Abba and Anonymi 3677 were expelled from the Convent of the Poplars and took up residence in the Convent of Nut in the village of 'Bdhyr.
After three years of residing in the Convent of Nut, Abba and his monks went to live in the Monastery of the Huts.
Abba continued to be persecuted and fled to the court of Empress Theodora.
Abba returned to the Convent of the Huts and died.
Abraham IV succeeded Abba as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.
Abraham IV died and was buried in the monastery.
Sergius of Amida succeeded Abraham IV as head of the Convent of John Urtaya
Sergius gained distinction in exile during the persecutions and embraced asceticism and abstinence.
Mar John built a hut near the huts of Mar Afwrsm in the year 700
Emperor Justinian died in the year 565/6 A. Gr. 877

The brothers of the Convent of John Urtaya and the other religious believers persevered during the persecutions, which began in 520/1 A. Gr. 832 and continued until the writing of this account in the year 567/8 A. Gr. 879

John went about preaching and teaching the Christian faith in Urtaya Urtaye and spoke the language of Urtaye. As such, many believed that John was Urtaya and called him by that name. John was actually Syrian.
John Urtaya's fame spread far and wide, attracting many followers including two excellent scribes from the Convent of Edessa at Amida, Samuel and Jonathan.

During the time that Jonathan and Samuel lived with Mar John Urtaya, they learned a great deal about asceticism and the Christian faith. The convent flourished, buildings were established, and the brotherhood grew to fifty in number.
John Urtaya died.
Samuel succeeded John Urtaya as the head of the convent.
Jonathan, who had left the monastery while John Urtaya was still alive, returned after his death and lived in a brotherly fashion with Samuel.
Samuel died.
Jonathan succeeded Samuel as head of the convent.
Jonathan governed the convent well before he died.
Job succeeded Jonathan as head of the convent.
Job governed the monastery well before he died.
The Convent of John Urtaya was founded in 388/9 A. Gr. 700
Abraham succeeded Job as head of the convent.
Abraham was from Amida and had a residence there. His mother, brothers, and kinsmen lived in Amida.
The Convent of John Urtaya closed in 566/7 A. Gr. 878

The monks serving under Abraham accused him of embezzling monastery funds in order to support his family. Abraham was innocent, but left the monastery to live in the city and lived the rest of his days longing for his former monastic existence.
The great senior Mar Samuel Archpresbyter dwelled in the Convent of John Urtaya during the time of its prosperity until the year 538/9 A. Gr. 850
Abraham II succeeded Abraham I as the head of the convent.
As Abraham II's reputation as an excellent leader grew, King Zeno gifted him with a village in Narda in the district of Ingelene
Abraham II gave half of the land that he received from King Zeno to the brothers of the Monastery of Zuknin.
The Convent of John Urtaya grew to include 400 brothers.
Abraham II was promoted to the bishopric in Urtaye in the district of Anzetene.
Anonymi 3673 of the Convent of John Urtaya urged Bishop Abraham to appoint a new head. Abraham chose Abraham the Shepherd, who was formerly a shepherd from the Village of Thella d Mikhana.
Abraham the Shepherd succeeded Abraham II as head of the Convent of John Urtaya.
Severus wrote a letter arguing that scriptural references to physical attributes do not indicate that God has a body. Rather they refer to divine powers.
Severus wrote a letter to Theognostus discussing Isaiah 61.1
Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymous 3721 on the subject of marriage and divorce.
Anonymous 3721 sent a letter to Severus of Antioch on the subject of marriage and divorce.
Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Abba on the subject of marriage and divorce.
Abba sent a letter to Severus of Antioch on the subject of marriage and divorce.
Severus wrote a letter to Phocas and Eupraxius discussing the humility of Christians and the incarnation of Christ.
Between 508 and 511, Severus wrote a letter to Constantine the bishop about the ordination of bishops and clergy in the wake of the Council of Chalcedon.
Asterius the Bishop and those with him came to Severus in Antioch.
Emperor Anastasius sent his formula of satisfaction to Flavian, prelate of Antioch.

John of Claudiopolis, when he received Severus in the house of Patrick, urged Severus to receive the synod of Chalcedon, not as a positive definition of faith, but as a rejection of Nestorius and Eutyches.

Severus responded to John by refusing to accept the synod of Chalcedon as a repudiation of Nestorius and Eutyches, because the Chalcedonian creed and the Tome of Leo support Nestorianism; Severus does not believe that anathematizing Eutyches makes the Council of Chalcedon legitimate, because the followers of Arius were still heretics even though they repudiated the teachings of Sabellius.
John asked Severus if Epiphanius had performed his ordinations correctly.
Severus recalled that Epiphanius had been brought up in the monasteries of Perga, practicing a life of virginity.
When Timothy had endured his exile from Alexandria, Epiphanius left his bishopric in Magydum and came to Alexandria, embracing communion with Timothy.
After Timothy had died and the orthodox began enduring persecution again, Epiphanius withdrew to Palestine where he met with Peter of Iberia and began ordaining priests.

Severus argued that by ordaining priests in a diocese that was not his own, Epiphanius was not violating the sacred canons, which only outlaws such behavior in the cases of bishops forcing themselves on other dioceses, citing the examples of Eusebius of Samosata during the controversy of Arius, Theodoret, Basil, and Gregory the Theologian.
Severus believed that he had convinced John to not affirm the council of Chalcedon.
Severus encouraged Constantine to follow his teaching and the advice of Peter the Presbyter and to be alert for John's blacksiding.
Severus wrote letters on similar themes to Oecumenius.
Severus sent a letter to Antoninus in which he affirmed the real, physical birth of Jesus during which Mary felt pain.
Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymi 3722 on the subject of his ordination, the legitimacy of his administration of the sacraments, and the issue of re-ordination.
Severus wrote a letter to Conon about the marriage of Conon's daughter. He merely recommended that she be given in marriage to someone of orthodox faith.
John wrote a letter to Severus about the marriage of Conon's daughter.
Severus wrote a letter to Alypius on the subject of him unlawfully dismissing his wife.
Severus wrote a letter to John.
John wrote a letter to Severus denouncing Timothy.
Meletius was ordained by Arians but later demonstrated his orthodoxy.
Severus wrote a letter to Theodore urging him to keep his monastic vows.
When Theodore took his monastic vows he considered entering the the house of the saintly presbyter Theodore but chose not to do so.
Severus wrote a letter to Theodore cautioning him against entering the monastic life unless his wife also agreed to do the same.
Severus wrote a letter to Solon concerning his ordination, piety, and relationship to unorthodox bishops.

Severus encouraged Solon to live a holy and virtuous life, modelling the piety of Jesus andthe martyrs, especially Thecla, so that the legitimacy of his ordination by a bishop outside of the diocese might be confirmed.

To defend his belief in the ordination of priests by those outside of a particular diocese, Severus appeals to the examples of Basil during the controversy surrounding Arius, and Gregory the Theologian.
Flavian, who was challengeing the ordination of Solon, had previously ordained a priest in Germanicupolis.
Following the example of Constantine, Severus encouraged Solon to commune only with orthodox clergy, rather than following the example of Anastasius who had supported the Henotikon.
Solon sent a letter to Severus of Antioch asking about the conditions for entering into communion with another person.
Severus sent a letter to Jannia concerning her leadership as archimandritess.
Theodore the Deacon asked Severus about the commands Jannia gave him.
Severus advises Jannia to rule with fear and mercy, bringing forth repentance through ascetic acts of penance, and dismissing women if the community is threatened by their actions.
Severus encourages Jannia to lead by example, citing the apostle Paul and King David as models.

Severus sent a letter to Oecumenius discussing the unity of Christ's nature without the confusion of the human and divine elements in him. He also insisted on anathematizing those who do confuse the natures.
Severus sent a letter to Isidore discussing the the trinity and Christology.
Isidore sent a letter to Severus asking about trinity and Christology.
Severus sent a letter to Peter, Ammonius, and Olympiodorus discussing Peter's ordination as bishop of Alexandria.
Severus, Peter the Iberian, Theodore, and Isaiah of Gaza checked the advances of the Chalcedonians.
Severus wrote a letter to Ammonius on the necessity of affirming correct theology but also anathematizing incorrect theology.
Athanasius wrote a letter indicating he accepted the Henotikon without specifically anathematizing the Council of Chalcedon or Leo's Tome.
John wrote a letter indicating he accepted the Henotikon without specifically anathematizing the Council of Chalcedon or Leo's Tome.
John wrote a letter to Dioscorus and Chaeremon
Ammonius wrote a letter to Severus defending Peter Mongus.
Severus wrote a letter to Ammonius about his lack of agreement wiht the decision to add Peter Mongus to the dyptichs in Alexandria.
After rejecting the Council of Chalcedon and the Tome of Leo, Peter Mongus communed with Chalcedonians.

In 511 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc. After his accession as bishop , Timothy wrote a synodical letter that he sent to John and others in which he did not anathematize the Council of Chalcedon.
John responded to the synodical letter of Timothy and urged him to anathematize the Council of Chalcedon.
Anastasios wrote a letter to John complaining about his refusal simply to accept the Henotikon without anathemas of Chalcedon. His letter cites letters by Peter Mongus, Athanasius, John, and John.
Peter Mongus wrote a letter indicating he accepted the Henotikon without specifically anathematizing the Council of Chalcedon or Leo's Tome.
Severus wrote a letter to Dioscorus on the subject of receiving Chalcedonians who sought communion with non-Chalcedonians.
Dioscorus wrote a letter to Severus indicating that he had received into communion Castor
Dioscorus communed with Castor.
Basil wrote a letter to Urbicius on the subject of refraining from communion with heretics.
Severus wrote a letter to Eleusinius on the subject of the ordination and theology of John of Cappadocia.
Eleusinius wrote a letter to Severus about a trial of some presbyters.
John of Cappadocia became bishop of Constantinople.
Menas and Isidore wrote a letter to Severus reporting that Epiphanius excommunicated Anonymi 3034 when they would not commune with him.
Severus wrote a letter to Archaelaus concerning the invalidity of heretics who adminsister bans.
Severus wrote a letter to Zacharias of Peleusium on the subject of avoiding communion with heretics.
Isidore sent a letter to Theodosius on the subject of Eusebius oppressing his congregation in order to build a lavish church building.
Severus wrote a letter to Dionysios on the subject of avoiding communion with heretics.
Dionysios met with Severus and affirmed the orthodox faith but later began to commune with heretics.
Severus wrote a letter to Cosmas on the subject of forgiving those who involuntarily commune with heretic provided they confess their sin.
Julian accidentally communed with heretics and confessed his sin.
Severus wrote a letter to Solon arguing that the blessings of heaven are spiritual and not physical; eating, drinking, etc.
Basil carried a letter from Solon to Severus introducing Epiphanius and Symbatius.
Severus sent a letter to Solon addressing a dispute involving Callistus that resulted in his deposition as deacon.
Paul and Musonius agreed that Callistus ought to be returned to the diaconate..
Solon sent a letter to Severus addressing a dispute involving Callistus that resulted in his deposition as deacon..
Severus wrote a letter to Solon disucssing episcopal authority and canon law.
Musonius sent a letter to Longinus seeking illicity gain.
Severus wrote a letter to Conon on the origin of human sinfulness.
Severus wrote a letter to Peter hoping to correct the bishop's views of ordinations that occur at the hands of those outside a particular diocese.
Peter sent a letter to Severus accusing him with performing invalid ordinations.
Peter sent a letter to Thomas accusing Severus of performing invalid ordinations.

Severus was aware of many letters written by Peter to himself and to the presbyter Thomas, wherein Peter accused Severus and others of breaking canon-law and tradition by allowing for ordinations outside of the diocese.

Severus defended his ordination practices by pointing out that many other godly bishops approved, including Julian, who allowed Severus to ordain the deacon Irenaeus, and Dionysius, who allowed Severus to ordain the deacon Anatolius.
Contrary to the opinion of Peter, Severus had not ordained Leontius out of need, but in order to honour the man.
Severus had become acquainted with Leontius through letters while living in Palestine.
In his letter, Peter reported to Severus that Leontius had shaken the stability of the Church in Apamea.
Severus encouraged Peter to ordain the scholastics John son of Matronian and Sergius.
Severus intended to ordain the scholastics Peter and Maximin.
Severus wrote a letter to Valieriena thanking God for her new position as archimandritess and giving advice on how to lead the holy virgins under her care.

Severus advises Valeriena to encourage the virgins to an ascetic life, suggesting their isolation from men, sharing common meals, discouraging the owning of enslaved people, and emphasize physical labour.
Severus wrote a letter to Simeon in which he urged him to remain as head of his monastery and not withdraw to live as an anchorite.
Simeon left his responsibilities as monastic head in order to live as an anchorite but Severus called him to return.
Severus wrote a letter to Nicias discussing the impiety of ordination by Nestorian bishops.

Severus commanded Nicias to remain faithful to the sacred canons by stripping the deacons and priests on Minidus who had been ordained by Nestorians of their honor, titles, and ability to administer the sacraments.
Some from Minidus and Uaris obtained ordination at the hands of Nestorian bishops.
Severus wrote a letter to Castor about dissensions between readers and sub-deacons in his church.
Severus argued that the order of deacons have greater honor than the readers of the church.
Anonymi 3038 wrote to Severus about the readers and and singers claiming more authority than them.
Severus encouraged Castor to preserve order by siding with the subdeacons over the readers and singers.
Severus urged Timostratus to take the issue of ordination seriously because many in Antioch and the royal city were seeking ordination.
Between 513 to 518, Severus wrote a letter to Timostratus the Duke about the importance of ordination.
Timostratus had previously written to Severus about ordination, upsetting the bishop.
Severus wrote a letter to Nicias on the subject of receiving heretical clergy who have repented and seek communion.
Nicias wrote a letter to Severus informing him that Gennadius doubted that heretical clergy who have repented could be received.
Theodore sent letters to Cosmas.
Severus wrote a letter to archimandrite of the monastery of Bassus about a controversy surrounding a corrupt bishop of Apamea.
Anonymous 3042 sent a letter to Severus.
Severus had appointed Cosmas bishop of Apamea before his death.
Severus admitted to the archimandrite that he never had confidence in Cosmas, or had previous knowledge of him, but that the religious presbyter Theodore had knowwn and written to him.
Cosmas resigned from his bishopric on account of blasphemy and sickness.
The God-loving bishops meeting in Antioch urged Severus to accept the resignation of Cosmas.
After Cosmas resigned, the God-loving bishop Peter was instated by Severus.
When Cosmas fell ill, he petitioned Severus several times to go visit him.
Deacon Elijah suggested to Severus that Cosmas wanted him to visit in order to repent and receive the oblation from bishop,so Severus went begrudgingly, not even greeting Cosmas when he came to him.
Cosmas did not repent before Severus but merely wanted to engage in conversation, prompting Severus to leave in disgust.
Between 514 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Cosmas and Polyeuctus, and Zeno about a conflict in diocesian jurisdiction.
Cosmas, Polyeuctus, and Zeno had appealed to Severus concerning issues of jurisdiction in their diocese.
Severus desired for Cosmas, Polyeuctus, Zeno, and those who were in conflict with them to come to Antioch because Isidore the bishop of Chalis had not been present to adjudicate.
Severus replied to a letter of John on the subject of not communing with heretics.
Anonymous 3778 wrote a letter to John disclosing false theology.
John wrote a letter to Severus commending his wife to Severus and discussing his refusal to commune with heretics.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Entrechius bishop of Anazarba about accusations against an heretical bishop.
Anonymi 3046 and Anonymi 3050 persisted in bringing charges against their bishop Procopius to Severus.
Severus decided not to call on Procopius, but instead sent the presbyter Theodosius to Entrechius in order to examine the accusations.
Procopius had attempted to profit off his ordinations, and had ordained Lampetius, a known follower of the heresy of Adelphius which had been condemned by the synod at Commanus in Armenia.
The heresy of Adelphius had been condemned by Soteric of Caesarea and the bishops of Cappadocia, the bishops of Pontus, and the bishops of Galatia.
Severus urged Entrechius to work with Theodosius in order to mete out justice on the ecclesiastical offenders.
Between 514 and 518, Severus sent a letter to Antoninus the bishop of Berrhoea about corrupt bishops and the legitimacy of some ordinations.
Antoninus had sent Antiochus the tribune to Severus in Antioch.
Severus praised Antiochus to the God-loving bishop Thomas.
A letter intended for Antoninus had been misaddressed to Severus.
Severus had not yet received a letter concerning a contentious ordination in Chalcis, a matter of concern for Antoninus.
Severus condemned the late bishop Simeon for being a greedy and corrupt bishop.
Severus told Antoninus that he was deliberating on the legitimacy of some people ordained by the bishop.
Between 513 and 518,Severus wrote to Antoninus bishop of Berrhoea about the treatment of Jews.
In his letters to Severus and his uncle Hypatius, Antoninus showed wisdom in his handling the presumptuous deeds of the Jews, who are beyond all forgiveness.
Meeting with the general, Severus counselled Antoninus to show restraint with the Jews, even though no punishment is severe enough for the arrogance of the Jews.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Misael, thanking him for his generosity and urging him not to become a solitary.
Misael delivered Severus's church from the persecution of gilas.
Severus rebuked Misael for his desire to leave public life in order to become a solitary.

To convince Misael to remain in his position, Severus cited several scripture passages, as well as an historical anecdote of Anonymous 3057 and Anonymous 3058 who gave up their solitude in order to combat the heresy of Arius.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Antoninus bishop of Berrhoea about forms of worship, Church property, and treatment of the Jews.
Antoninus had accused Severus of staying silent after administering the Eucharist.
Severus sent a letter to Antoninus carried by John the scholastic.
Antoninus had sent Mark to Antioch in order to give presents to the Christians there.
Severus assured Antoninus that he would do everything in his power to ensure that the estates near Beth Remsha would remain in the Church's possession.
Severus again counselled Antoninus to show restraint with the Jews.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Misael defending his ordination practices.
Though Severus had initiallly held to a strict interpretation of the Church's ordination practices, the poverty and necessity of the Church forced him to change his practices.
Severus complained to Misael about officials like Eleutherius who were annoyed by his ordination practices.
Severus asked Misael to defend him and his practices before those like Eleutherius who were causing distress.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Entrechius about the appointment of Anonymous 3064 in Rhosus.
Clergy and residents of Rhosus petitioned Severus to allow Anonymous 3064 to be instituted as their bishop.
Severus urged the clergy and residents of Rhosus to include three other eligible and viruous men in their petition.
Between 514 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Solon, bishop of Seleucia in Isauria about conflicts over bishops in his diocese.
Severus was compelled to write because of the constant evil things being done in Isauria.
Last year, Severus compelled bishop Paul of Olba to return to his flock.
Paul refused to carry out the counsel of Severus to remove the names of those who affirmed the synod of Chalcedon.
Because Paul has an ordinarily simple disposition, Solon should not frighten him like a child by forcing him to sign documents.
After a dispute with Hilarian about a monastery and a presumptuous and illeagl forging of signatures by Callistus, Paul fled to the royal city.
Until an investigation can be undertaken, Severus believed that Callistus and those who sided from Hilarian should be censored from ministry.
Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Victor on the subject of the monk John and his lust for money.
In 515, Severus and the bishops gathered in Antioch wrote a letter to the bishops under the metropolis of Apamea about their embrace of heresy and mistreatment of the orthodox.
The bishops of Antioch asked Peter of Apamea why no one had assembled from his city.

Peter told the bishops how the Apamean bishops had broken communion from the orthodox, and submitted a petition to Severus concerning the injustice that he had experienced at the hands of the unorthodox.
Severus and the bishops of Antioch urged the Apamean bishops to repent of their sin.
In 515, Severus wrote a letter to the Master of the Offices about the sins of the unorthodox bishops.
Rufinus, who had brought a letter from the Master of Offices to Severus summoning him to Heraclea, was unable to bring back the response because of a disease of the eyes.
The enslaved person Leontius brought the message from Severus to the Master of Offices in Constantinople.

The God-loving bishops of Antioch thought it necessary to warn the bishop of Epiphania, the bishop of Arethusa, and the bishop of Rhaphania about the monastic-heads and leaders who have broken communion with the orthodox.
Severus accused the unorthodox of denying scripture, canon-law, and the authority of the bishops, because they insulted the orthodox bishops of Antioch.
Musonius sent a letter to Longinus seeking illicit gain.
Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymi 3726 on the subject of Musonius, especially his greed, pride, and disruptive behavior.
Sometime before 0518 Musonius traveled from Isaurai to Alexandria.
Musonius was convicted of lending money at interest in the episcopal court of Severus of Antioch.
Severus wrote a letter to the monastery at Tagai stating that re-baptism and re-anointing are not required of those who repent of their Chalcedonianism.
When Severus became bishop of Antioch, he opposed those who insisted that Chalcedonians who repented of their theology needed to be re-baptized or re-annointed.
When Stephen united with bishops in the regions of Palestine and Alexandria he opposed those who insisted that Chalcedonians who repented of their theology needed to be re-baptized or re-annointed.
In 516 or 517, Severus wrote a letter to Solon the bishop of Seleucia in Isauria about the controversy between Musonius and Paul.
Because Musonius had fled from Meloe, and Paul had left Olba, Severus advised Solon to appoint new bishops, or at the very least to petition the emperor to assemble a council of bishops in Isauria.
For his other questions, Severus referred Solon to Oecumenius.
Between 514 and 518, Severus wrote to Theotecnus the Chief Physician about the bishops of Constantinople affirming the teachings of the council of Chalcedon.
Most of the bishops assembled at Constantinople, except the Romans, were found to be orthodox, but the pious bishops Eleusinius and Proclus had fled the royal city.
The synod in Constantinople intended to affirm the council of Chalcedon as a repudiation of the teachings of Eutyches.
Severus had corresponded with the Master of Offices in Constantinople through Leontius about the illegitimacy of corrupt bishops.
Severus had written to Dionysius of Tarsus concerning the veneration of Nestorius in that area.
A presbyter in the village of Pessinus became sick by possession of a demon, causing him to wander around the countryside.
Severus suggested that Dionysius treat the man with sympathy, but to ensure that he cannot administer the sacraments.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Dionysius the bishop of Tarsus about a demon-possessed presbyter.
Between 515 and 517, Severus wrote a letter to Solon, bishop of Seleucia in Isauria concerning the absence of Paul of Olba's absence.
Because Paul had been long absent from his bishopric in Olba, Severus urged Solon to replace him.

When Paul criticized Hilarian for ordaining priests outside his jurisdiction, Severus had initially prohibited those priests from ministering until an investigation could take place; with Paul's absence, Severus now believed that those men should be reinstated.
Sometime between 513 and 518 , Severus sent a letter to Philoxenus of Mabbug detailing his request to Philoxenus , of Doliche that Romulus , be granted permission to conduct prayers in Antioch .
Sometime between 513 and 518 , prominent men in Antioch petitioned Severus to allow Romulus to conduct prayers in Antioch even though he was under the authority of Philoxenus , bishop of Doliche .
Sometime between 513 and 518 , Severus sent a letter to Philoxenus , bishop of Doliche requesting that he grant permission to one of his clergymen, Romulus , to conduct prayers in Antioch .
Between 513 and 516, Severus wrote a letter to Musonius and Alexander concerning the orthodoxy of Eastern bishops and the evil of poetry.

Severus and the bishops of the East had drawn up a synodal letter to John the archbishop of Alexandria, affirming orthodoxy and condemning the council of Chalcedon, the teachings of Nestorius, and the Tome of Leo.
Due to the annoyance caused by Martyrius the poet, Severus condemned the practice of poetry, even among the clergy, as an instigator of passions and fornication.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to the devout monks of the blessed Lord Isaac about a legal dispute they were involved in, and a candidate for bishop among the brothers.
A dispute between Antipater and the monks had been settled by the magistrates.
The inhabitants of Anasartha proposed episcopal candidates to Severus.
Severus desired to ordain Stephen as bishop over the Anasarthians.
Severus commanded the brothers to compel Stephen to accept the position of bishop over the Anasarthians.
Severus wrote a letter to the Fathers on the subject of baptism and ordination.
Anonymous 3780 performed ordinations against canon law and made many false oaths.
Cyrus falsely claimed to be a priest and performed invalid ordinations.
the Fathers wrote a letter to Severus about Marinus having trouble with the clergy in Beirut.
Marinus rejected the incarnation and adopted the errors of Eutyches and Valentinus.
Severus sent Eusebius and Victor to urge Marinus to repent and abandon his Eutychian views of the incarnation.
Severus asked that his letter be read to Zoninus, Irenaeus, Zenobius, and Eubulus.
Severus refused to recognize ordinations by Theodotus and Gregory but he did accept the baptisms they performed.
Severus wrote a letter to Theotecnus on the subject of receiving clergy who repented after holding heretical views.
Severus wrote a letter to Dionysius on the subject of the repentance of Mark and whether he should become an archimandrite.
Basil wrote a letter to Severus about uncanonical ordinations.
Dionysius forced Basil to perform an unlawful ordination.
When Dionysius attempted to force Basil to perform an unlawful ordination, Severus urged Theotecnus and John to oppose this.
Theotecnus wrote a letter to Severus seeking advice regarding the decision to receive the presbyter Mark after he repented of heresy.
Theotecnus wrote a letter to Severus about the theological erros of Romanus.
Severus urged Theotecnus to condemn Romanus in a synodical letter.
Severus wrote a letter to Dionysius on the subject of the repentance of Mark and whether he should become an archimandrite.
Basil wrote a letter to Urbicius on the subject of refraining from communion with heretics.
Severus defended Julian against charges that he attempted to mislead Anastasios.
Severus wrote a letter to Stephen promoting the ordination of the kinsman of Marinus and discussing the monk John.
Marinus wrote a letter to Severus asking him to promote his kinsman as a clergyman in Apamea.

Severus received a letter from the monastery of Akiba seeking his support in the matter of John, a monk of that monastery who was absent without permission. They feared that he would be ordained without their consent.
Anonymous 3782 carried a letter written by Severus recommeding him for ordination to Stephen.
Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to the monastery of Mar Bassus urging them to remove a monk from their monastery who unlawfully abandoned his wife and children when he entered the monastery.
Between 513 and 518, Severus sent a letter to Cassian concerning the treatment of a man whose genitals had been cut off.

In reference to Thomas, Severus refutes Cassian's blaming of the mutilation on the corrupt bishop Julian, suggesting instead that Thomas be allowed to remain in the clergy on the condition that the accident was due to illness performed by a physician.
Severus sent a letter to Cassian concerning the vexing question of the ordination of Dorotheus who had been castrated by a physician and not of his own will.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Aurelius about showing a kind disposition to sin, and how to handle cases of self-mutilation.

With regard to the mutilation of Thomas, Severus advises Aurelius to allow him his priestly office if the mutilation was performed by a physician because of an illness, but to deny him if Thomas mutilated himself.
Severus also wrote to Cassian, advocating the view that Thomas's mutilation was medicinal.
Severus wrote a letter to Stephen on the subject of reading the lives of saints.
Stephen sent a letter to Severus requesting a historical treatment of the life of Simeon the Stylite. The letter was carried by Sergius.
Severus wrote a letter to Anastasius arguing that the validity of sacraments is not based on the morality of the clergy.
Severus sent the eucharistic elements to Anastasius because he was unable to find an orthodox priest to provide it.

Sometime between 515-18 Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to the magister militum Hypatius about the case of Julian who petitioned Hypatius to overturn the ruling of an ecclesiastical court that found him guilt of using church property for personal benefit.

Sometime between 515-18 Severus of Antioch and a group of clergy and scholastics ruled against Julian in a dispute regarding church property in Tarsus. Julian attempted to appeal to the magister militum Hypatius.
Severus wrote a letter to the monks of Mar Isaac discussing the abomination of desolation and the antichrist.
Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymous 3738 requesting that the monk Nonnus appear in Antioch to face charges of misappropriating church funds.

Sometime during the episcopacy of Severus of Antioch Nonnus fled Antioch when faced with charges of misappropriating church funds. He then entered the monastery of Saint Simeon and refused attempts to return him for trial.

Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch answered a letter from the wife of Calliopius on the subjects of Christology and the women teaching theology; namely that they should learn theology and teach other women but not men.

Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to Eutychian the governor of Apamea urging him not to join in worship with Anonymous 3740 because he had been lawfully deprived of his priestly office.

Sometime during the episcopacy of Severus of Antioch Eutychian the governor of Apamea joined in celebrating martyrs and dedicating a church with Anonymous 3740 despite the fact that he had lawfully deprived of his priestly office.

Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to the clergy of Antaradus regarding a difficult set of circumstance surrounding their efforts to have a bishop ordained for their city and the case of Leontius, a deacon who had been disciplined because of his sin but was unrepentant and indeed sought to become head deacon.
Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch consulted with Anastasios I regarding the difficult circumstances surrounding the lack of a bishop in Antaradus.

Sometime during his episcopacy Severus of Antioch received a petition from Stephen, a deacon in Antaradus requesting the intervention of Severus in the case of Leontius who had been removed from the sacred tables for taking a second wife after his ordination as a deacon but allowed to keep ministering. Stephen opposed his lifestyle and his attempts to become head deacon.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Stephen, bishop of Tripoli about a presbyter Stephen who came to Tripoli without a dismissory letter from his original diocese.
Stephen had been ordained by force.
Appealing to Cyril's letter to Nestorius and the example of Severus the presbyter, Severus urged Stephen to accept the ordination of Stephen because heretics cannot be expected to follow canon-law.
Severus suggested that Stephen ensure that a cross remain erected in front of the house of Theodore the governor.
Severus wrote a letter arguing against rebaptism and reanointing for those converting from Chalcedonianism.
The Council of Nicaea stipulated different remedies for different heresies. Trinitarian baptisms were considered valid but followers of Paul of Samosata needed to be re-baptized upon conversion.
The Council of Laodicea stipulated followers of Photinus and Novatus only needed to be re-anointed upon conversion but not re-baptized.

The Council of Ephesus in 431 heard from Charisius that many in Lydia followed a creed by Theodore of Mopsuestia. In rejecting it and Nestorianism, the Council required only an orthodox profession of faith without the need for be re-baptism or re-anointing.

When working to reunite Egypt and the East after the Council of Ephesus Paul brokered an agreement that conversion from Nestorianism required only an orthodox profession of faith without the need for re-baptism or re-anointing.

Theophilus of Alexandria wrote a letter to Flavian of Antioch urging his to accept clergy ordained by his opponents during the Melitian Schism without the need for re-baptism or re-anointing. He cites the case of Anastasius in Rome and the case of Auxentius and Ambrose in Milan.
Timothy of Alexandria urged accepting Diophysites ordained by Proterius without re-ordination, re-baptism, or re-anointing.
Non-Chalcedonians in the East accept converts from Chalcedonianism without re-baptism, or re-anointing, re-ordination.
Theodotus introduced the practice of re-anointing those converting to non-Chalcedonianism.
Cyprian and the Council of Carthage concluded that heretics should be re-baptized upon coming to orthodoxy.
Dionysius of Alexandria wrote a letter to Dionysius and Stephen arguing that all Trinitarian baptisms were valid, even if performed by heretics.
Severus wrote a letter to Archelaus answering his question about John 22 and arguing that the bible does not say that the John would not experience death before the return of Christ.
Archelaus wrote a letter to Severus asking about John 22 and the claim made by some that the apostle John and other disciples would not experience death before the return of Christ.
Severus wrote a letter to Theodore of Olba on the subject of Anonymous 3783 who took communion and later said he did not know whether he had ever been baptized.

After years of living as a monk and regularly taking communion, Anonymous 3784 witnessed a baptism for the first time and admitted that he had never been baptized. After conducting a formal investigation in order to ensure that they avoid re-baptism, Anonymous 3784 was baptized.
Theodore of Olba wrote a letter to Severus on the subject of Anonymous 3783 who took communion and later said he did not know whether he had ever been baptized.
Anonymous 3783 took communion and later told the clergy that he did not know whether he had ever been baptized.

Cyril of Alexandria faced a situation where two mothers did not know which of their two children had been baptized. To avoid the risk of re-baptism, he dipped both into the font and while saying that only the one who had not been baptized was being baptized.
Severus wrote a letter to Dionysius disagreeing with his decision to commune with Indacus. He urged Dionysius to bring Indacus to repentance.
Severus wrote a letter to Nonnus on the disobedience of Pelagius.
Pelagius was summoned to be judged by Severus and the Count of the East. He was convicted of sowing discord and exiled from his monastery the House of Thomas.
Pelagius brought Diophysites into the monastery and even supported them in taking communion against canon law.
Severus reluctantly permitted the commemoration of Epiphanius of Magydum.
Severus judged Pelagius unworthy to reside in the monastery of Mor Tumo.
Severus reqquired the monastery of Mor Tumo to erect a public declaration of the orthodox (non-Chalcedonian) faith.
Between 513 and 518, Severus wrote a letter to Eucharius about the trial of Firminus.
Though the people of Paltus had found Firminus guilty, Severus wanted to withhold judgment until a formal trial in Antioch could be organized.

Severus sent a letter to Oecumenius discussing the unity of Christ's nature without the confusion of the human and divine elements in him. He also insisted on anathematizing those who do confuse the natures.
Oecumenius sent a letter to Severus discussing Christology and expressing doubts about non-Chalcedonian Christology.
Anatolius expressed doubts about non-Chalcedonian Christology but Severus convinced him to abandon them.
Sometime after his removal from episcopal office Severus of Antioch exchanged letters with John and John on the subject of two bishops involved in a dispute over who had precedence.
Severus responded to a letter of Scholasticus discussing the blessings of God being taken from the Jews and given to the Christians.

Sometime between 519-520 Severus of Antioch sent a letter to John and John on the subjects of whether or not non-Chalcedonian exiles in Egypt should take communion; and the question of what to do about Epimachus , a devout man ordained to the clergy but who had entered into a second marriage; and questions about the ordination of deacons and deaconesses in monasteries.
Sometime before 520 Isidore re-ordained deacons whom Severus had already ordained. Severus did not object to this because this ordination took place far outside of his jurisdiction.
Severus responded to a letter of Anastasia the deaconess answering her questions about Matthew 24.20 and other passages of the bible that address the end of the world.
Anastasia the deaconess wrote a letter to Severus asking questions about Matthew 24.20 and other passages of the bible that address the end of the world.
Severus wrote a letter attempting to administer his see while in exile. He discussed being forced to commune with heretics and perseverance in the face of persecution.

Severus wrote a letter to Antioch in an attempt to administer his see while in exile. He discussed apsotasy and perseverance in the face of persecution as well as repentance for those truly seeking it.
Severus responded to a letter of Sergius addressing his questions Matthew 17.2 and other passages of the bible that suggest greater honor being given to some people.
Sergius wrote a letter to Severus asking about Matthew 17.2 and other passages of the bible that suggest greater honor being given to some people.
Betwen 521 and 531,Severus wrote a letter to Simeon the Presbyter about those who gave up the lifestyle of Simeon the Stylite.
Severus wrote a letter to the monastery of Isaac on the subject of receiving the repentant.

Sometime in the early 520s Severus of Antioch sent a letter to John and John on the subjects of Christian slaves sold by Jewish owners, fellowship with clergy who accept non-Chalcedonian theology but remain in communion with Chalcedonians, and the persecution of non-Chalcedonians.
Sometime in the early 520s Anonymi 3108 and Anonymi 3105 in Isauria suffered persecution and expulsion at the hands of Stephen. Anonymi 3108 went into exile.
Sometime in the early 520s Stephen sent Anonymi 3746 to bring back Anonymi 3108 who had fled.
Sometime in the early 520s Isidore, Thomas, and Epimachus traveled to Pelusium to support the non-Chalcedonian cause.
Anonymi 3744 sold Anonymous 3745 whom they had enslaved.
Sometime in the early 520s certain clergy in Cilicia Prima were remiss in resisting Chalcedonians.
Anonymi 3733 deposed Paul and later Anonymi 3732 upheld the ruling.

Sometime between 519-520 Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymi 3732 on the subject of the deposition of clergy and how those deposed by a local synod may appeal to a higher authority and be reinstated but only with agreement of the bishops who originally condemned him. Moreover, they may not exercise their priestly duties while appeal is pending.

After the Council of Ephesus, Paul petitioned Cyril of Alexandria to grant forgiveness to Dorotheus, Eutherius, Himerius, and Helladius. For the sake of church unity, Cyril of Alexandria agreed on the condition that they condemn Nestorius.
Severus of Antioch sent a letter to John and John on how to interact with heretics seeking repentance and how to decide with whom one may commune.
John and Sergius caused problems in Egypt when dreams and prophesies made them hesitate to commune with the non-Chalcedonians there.
Mitras caused problems in Egypt when he refused to commune with the non-Chalcedonians there.
Those who thought the Henotikon was insufficient without an anathema of Chalcedon refused to commune with those who thought is was sufficient.

Anatolius prophesied the death of those who communed with non-Chalcedonians who accepted the Henotikon even though it did not anathematize Chalcedon. He was forced to repent when his prophecies did not come true.

Severus healed a man with boils who thought he was going to die because Anatolius prophesied the death of those who communed with non-Chalcedonians who accepted the Henotikon even though it did not anathematize Chalcedon.

John and John sent a letter to Severus of Antioch discussing the persecution of non-Chalcedonians in the East, and on the ordination of those who originally received ordination from heretics but wish to join the non-Chalcedonians.
Athanasius attempted to refute Arian claims that their theology agreed with the theology of Dionysius.
Basil demonstrated inconsistencies in Dionysius's theology.
Silvanus, although ordained by Chalcedonians, sought to be a clergyman with the non-Chalcedonians. He was to follow the procedure set down by Timothy Aelurus which required penance.
Severus wrote a letter to John and John in which he praises the recipients and discusses receiving the repentant into communion, natural disasters, and Nestorians.
Sergius declared that the Council of Chalcedon was consistent with the theology of Diodore, Theodore, and Nestorius.
John and John wrote a letter to Severus about Ascalon.
John and John wrote a letter to Severus in which they discussed receiving the repentant into communion, natural disasters, and Nestorians.
Thomas visited Severus and other exiled bishops in Egypt.
Severus, John, and John witnessed an unusual astronomical event that Severus interpreted as a sign of God's discipline.
On 14 October 520 there was an earthquake in Egypt.
There was a plague in certain cities in Egypt, especially Athrib.
No later than 520, Stephen brought books to Severus who was in exile in Egypt.

Sometime between 519-520 Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymi 3753 about the attempts of Gregory and Isaiah to falsely claim episcopal status. He refuted their claims with references to scripture, canon law, and the lifestyles of these men.

Sometime around 519-520 Gregory attempted to claim he had been legitimately ordained a bishop and claim episcopal authority in Antioch. He attempted to claim he held authority based on his ordination in Diocaesarea.
Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah attempted to claim he had been legitimately ordained a bishop and claim episcopal authority in Emesa.
Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah produced false canons in an attempt to claim that his ordination by one bishop was lawful.
Sometime before 519 Isaiah travelled to Egypt and Pamphylia seeking support for his claim to episcopal office.
Severus buried Epiphanius in the monastery of Abba Peter the Iberian.
Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah attempted to demonstrate his sanctity in the city of Alexandria by raising Anonymous 3754 from the dead. He was unsuccessful and fled.
Severus wrote a letter to Proclus and Eusebuna on the subject of how to readmit the lapsed cleric Cyrus.
Proclus and Eusebuna wrote a letter to Severus on the subject of how to readmit the lapsed cleric Cyrus.
Cyrus was a lapsed clergyman who sought to be reinstated without signing a written declaration of orthodox faith.

Sometime between 519 and 538 Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to Proclus discussing the difficulties of being a bishop with a wife and child. He encouraged Proclus that his situation was not unique and urged him to call his wayward daughter to repentance.
Between 519 to 535, Severus wrote a letter to Caesaria concerning falsified letters and the good of Christian marriage.
Anonymi 3115 were circulating theological treatises, falsely bearing the name of Severus.
A devout presbyter from the East brought many forged letters and treatises to Severus.
In reference to the spurious writings, Severus likens himself to Basil, who addressed forgeries in letters to Orobiane, Chalane, and Neocaesarea.

In response to Caesarea's desire to leave her marriage to live a sanctified life, Severus encourages her to remain in her marriage, stating that to leave her husband even for pure reasons would be a grave sin, and that great glory is given to God by faithful wives and mothers.
Sometime between 519 and 525 Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Didymus on the subject of a barbarian incursion and the persecution of the non-Chalcedonians.
Sometime between 519 and 525 there was a barbarian incursion into Roman territory.

Sometime after the end of his episcopacy Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to Thecla discussing her devoutness and answering questions she had posed to Stephen about deacons baptizing in extraordinary situations and whether or not to baptize someone unable to make a profession of faith.
Sometime between 519-538 a very ill baby was baptized by a deacon in the absence of a priest. This raised questions about the legitimacy of the baptism.
Sometime between 519-538 questions arose about whether a boy unable to make a profession of faith should be considered a believer or an unbeliever.
Severus responded to a letter of Caesaria hypatissa answering her questions about the circumcision of Jesus and what happened to his foreskin.
Caesaria hypatissa wrote a letter to Severus asking questions about the circumcision of Jesus and what happened to his foreskin.
Severus responded to a letter of Caesaria hypatissa answer her question about apokatastasis and indicating that he believed the blessings of heaven and the torments of hell both to be eternal.
Caesaria hypatissa wrote a letter to Severus asking whether or not he held to the doctrine of apokatastasis.
Someone circulated a letter falsely attributed to Severus that indicated he held to the doctrine of apokatastasis.
Severus wrote a letter to John of Tella, Philoxenus of Doliche, and Thomas of Dara on the subject of receiving into communion those baptized in another confession.
When Charisius appeared before the Council of Nicaea and repented of his Nestorianism he was admitted to communion based on a signed profession of faith. He was not re-anointed.
Timothy Aelurus expelled Theodotus from the priesthood for re-anointing repentant heretics.
John of Tella, Philoxenus of Doliche, and Thomas of Dara wrote a letter to Severus on the subject of receiving into communion those baptized in another confession.
Severus responded to a letter of Caesaria hypatissa answering her questions about Matthew 14.25 and referencing biblical passages dealing with the incarnation.
Caesaria hypatissa wrote a letter to Severus asking questions about Matthew 14.25.
Severus responded to a letter of Sergius answering his questions about Enoch and Elijah. He argued that they were still alive but had not yet experienced immortality.
Sergius wrote a letter to Severus asking about Enoch and Elijah being caught up into heaven and whether or not they died.
Severus wrote a letter to Sergius and Marion on the subject of converts form Chalcedonianism doing penance but not being re-baptized or re-anointed and the subject of needing more ordained clergy.
Sergius and Marion wrote a letter to Severus on the subject of what rites to perform when receiving converts form Chalcedonianism.
Julian, lacking needed clergy, sought the ordination of priests and deacons by Sergius and Marion.
Severus wrote a letter to Sergius and Marion in which he warmly greeted Maximin.
Severus responded to a letter of Anastasia the deaconess, answering her questions about difficult passages in the Bible. He used allegory to explain some passages.
Severus denounced Isaiah for telling lies about him, claiming that Severus taught that the body of Christ underwent corruption while he was in the grave.
Anastasia the deaconess wrote a letter to Severus asking him to clarify various difficult passages in the Bible.
Severus responded to a letter of Constantine of Laodicea answering his questions about difficult passages in the bible.
Constantine of Laodicea wrote a letter to Severus asking questions about difficult passages in the bible.
Between 519 and 538, Severus sent a letter to Georgia, daughter of Anastasia expressing the merits of coming to marriage as an adult.
Anastasia and her husband were ashamed that their daughter had not yet been married.
Severus encourages Georgia to glory in her unmarried state, because time will make her more mature, wise, and intelligent, allowing her to be a greater help, model, and encouragement to her husband.
Severus wrote a letter to Eustace on the subject of troubling thoughts and a legal dispute over an inheritance.
Eustace wrote a letter to Severus on the subject of troubling thoughts and a legal dispute over an inheritance.

Severus wrote a letter to John the scholastic in which he answered questions posed by another. The questions dealt with repentance for refusing to submit to monastic discipline and repentance for self-castration in one's youth.

Severus wrote a letter to Probus discussing the seven days of creation and the judgment of Christ in the apocalypse.
Severus wrote a letter Sergius answering his question about the risen Jesus appearing to the disciples after a night of fishing. He offers an allegorical and anti-Jewish interpretation.
Sergius wrote a letter to Severus asking about the risen Jesus appearing to the disciples after a night of fishing.
Paul of Ephesus rejected the Chalcedonian confession and joined an encyclical declaring miaphysite Christology.
Paul of Ephesus and Timothy of Alexandria communed together after the miaphysite confession of Paul.

Sometime between 519 and 525 Severus of Antioch anwered a letter he received from Photius and Andrew on the subject of receiving clergy from Nestorian and Diphysite groups who renounce their heresy and make a right confession and on whether or not catechumens, the demon possed, and penitents should be present for the Lord's Supper. Severus of Antioch states that after a period of repentance they should be received into the same rank without re-baptism or re-ordination.
When Severus became bishop of Antioch people led by Theodotus insisted that converts from the Nestorian heresy be re-anointed.

Severus wrote a letter to Ammian and Epagathus on the following subjects: the name of Ammian's newborn son, Ammian's request that the eucharistic elements be sent to him, and Severus's refusal because the sacrament is not dependent upon the standing of the clergy who administers it.

Severus appeals to Gregory of Nazianzus to prove the efficacy of the Eucharist regardless of its administrator. Just as Baptism is valid regardless of the priest, and the seal of the king is valid regardless if it's set it in gold or wax, so the Eucharist is efficacious regardless of the priest.
Early in the sixth century, Severus wrote a letter to Misael the Deacon concerning the efficacy of the eucharist from impious priests.

Severus asserts that an oblation delivery is only necessary for those without bishops, making it unnecessary for Misael. Severus appeals to the scriptural story of Elijah and the ravens, asserting that even impious priests can be vessels to deliver the Eucharist.

Sometime after his episcopacy Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to Isidora about the death of her fellow nun Anonymous 3759; her decision not to leave her monastery to see Anonymous 3759 before her death, and questions about where she should be buried.

Severus wrote a letter to Thomas of Germaniciea discussing in detail a late addition in the the Gospel of Matthew indicating that the soldier who pierced the side of Christ did so before Christ had died.

During the investigation of Macedonius II that led to his exile, there was close examination of copies of the Gospel of Matthew showing that someone had falsely added the story of the soldier piercing the side of Christ.

John bar Aphthonia sent a letter to Andrew.

John died by suicide.

Severus wrote a letter to Andrew concerning the holy virgins, free women, and the death of Zosimus.
Anonymi 3126 sent a letter to Severus of Antioch.
Andrew made a way for the freewomen to visit the bones of Peter.
Andrew sent a letter to Severus asking about whether it is lawful to venerate the remains of martyrs when they are held in the churches of heretics and informing him of the death of Zosimus.

Sometime between 519-525 Severus of Antioch wrote a letter to Anonymous 3751 addressing his request to intervene in various interpersonal disputes. Severus emphasized proper order in judicial matters, especially the need for multiple witnesses.

Severus of Antioch and Anonymi 3729 exchanged letters on questions of whether or not there would be sufficient ordained clergy to adminster the Lord's Supper and baptism to the women. Severus wrote a letter to Maron on the union of natures in Christ.
Severus sent a letter to Eleusinius discussing Christology.
Eleusinius sent a letter to Severus discussing Christology.
Severus sent a letter to Eleusinius discussing Christology.

Severus wrote a letter to Eleusinius discussing Christ's existence before the Incarnation.
Severus sent a letter to Entrechius discussing Christology and the Incarnation.

Thomas the Syncellus sent a letter to Severus seeking answers to a series of questions about Christology.
Severus wrote a letter to Thomas discussing the union of humanity and divinity in Christ.
Severus wrote a letter to Thomas discussing the union of natures in Christ.
Severus wrote a letter to Thomas discussing purity and fasting.
Severus wrote a letter to Isidore on the subject Christology.
Severus sent a letter to Isidore discussing the Trinity and opposition to heresy.
Isidore sent a letter to Severus.
Severus sent a letter to John and John discussing Christology.
John and John sent a letter to Severus discussing Christology.
Severus sent a letter to Jonathan, Samuel, and John discussing Christology and the Trinity. This letter was to be circulated among the Christians of Anbar and Hirtha dNumn.

Severus wrote a letter to the clergy, magistrates, and people of Emesa about a brother who refused to repent after he insisted that Christ, after the resurrection, had no flesh. Severus urged forgiveness.
Dorotheus presented a petition to Emperor Marcian requesting the recall of Nestorius from exile.
Severus sent a letter to John, John, and Theodore discussing the Trinity.

Severus recommended that Elisha sell the complete copy of that Bible that had been owned by John before his death, and use the funds for the care of the poor.
Elisha wrote a letter to Severus about financial assistance for him in exile and requesting his work against John the Grammarian.
